premortem_metadata.project: What's Poppin! - All-in-one city directory app
premortem_metadata.methodology: Premortem failure analysis based on market research and competitive landscape
premortem_metadata.perspective: Assume the project failed spectacularly in 18 months - identify why

failure_scenario: It is now April 2027. What's Poppin! has shut down after burning through $5M in funding. User acquisition stalled at 50K users (90% below target), day-30 retention was 4% (vs 15% goal), and only 500 events were created monthly. The app was delisted from app stores and the team disbanded.

identified_risks.risk_name: Cold Start Problem - No Events, No Users; No Users, No Events
identified_risks.description: Classic two-sided marketplace failure. Event organizers won't post on platform with no audience. Users won't download app with no events. Chicken-and-egg problem proved insurmountable.
identified_risks.failure_mode: Launched in 5 cities simultaneously but spread resources too thin. No critical mass in any single market. Event organizers tried the platform, saw zero RSVPs, and never returned.
evidence_from_research: Travel apps have 2.8% day-30 retention - users need immediate value or they churn
Meetup has low 3.0 satisfaction rating, indicating community platforms struggle with engagement
92% of local engagement happens on established platforms (Google/Bing/Apple/Facebook)
mitigation_strategies: Launch in SINGLE city (Austin or Nashville) and dominate before expanding
Pre-seed platform with 500+ events via partnerships BEFORE user launch
Partner with existing event organizers (breweries, music venues, nonprofits) for guaranteed content
Scrape/aggregate public events from Eventbrite/Facebook as initial seed data
Offer $500-1000 launch bonuses to first 100 event organizers
Run 3-month beta with 1,000 hand-recruited users before public launch
identified_risks.success_criteria: 1,000+ events in launch city BEFORE app store release, 10,000 waitlist signups pre-launch

identified_risks.risk_name: Failed to Beat Industry-Worst 2.8% Retention Rate
identified_risks.description: App installed during trip planning but never opened again. Users reverted to familiar apps (Google Maps, Yelp). No daily habit formation, no push notification engagement, no reason to return.
identified_risks.failure_mode: Product designed like travel app (episodic use) instead of social app (daily utility). Users came for events, found nothing interesting, and uninstalled. No gamification, no social proof, no FOMO triggers.
evidence_from_research: Travel apps: 18% day-1 retention, 7.6% day-7, 2.8% day-30
Hotel apps used once per vacation - no retention mechanism
Daily utility apps achieve 25-30% day-30 retention (10x travel apps)
mitigation_strategies: Design for DAILY local discovery, not episodic travel
Push notifications for events happening tonight (time-sensitive FOMO)
Personalized daily digest: 'Your city today' with 5 curated recommendations
Gamification: Check-in badges, 'Explorer' levels, streak rewards
Social features: See what friends are attending, share plans, create groups
Habit loops: Daily challenges ('Try 3 new restaurants this week'), rewards for engagement
In-app benefits: Exclusive deals for active users, early access to ticket sales
identified_risks.success_criteria: 15% day-30 retention (5x industry), 3+ sessions per week per user, 40% weekly active users

identified_risks.risk_name: Built 'Everything App' and Delivered Nothing Well
identified_risks.description: Tried to compete with Yelp + Eventbrite + Meetup + Google Maps simultaneously. Spread engineering resources across 50 features. Shipped mediocre discovery, buggy event creation, broken social features, and unreliable navigation. Users complained 'app tries to do too much but nothing works'.
identified_risks.failure_mode: Built for 12-month vision in Month 1. MVP had 40 screens, 15-step onboarding, and confused value proposition. Users didn't understand what problem the app solved. TechCrunch review: 'Ambitious but half-baked'.
identified_risks.impact: HIGH - Poor reviews, negative PR, failed retention
evidence_from_research: City discovery app users complain about 'overwhelming information'
Eventbrite/Meetup offer 'minimal customization' and still succeed
Users already use 3-5 apps - asking them to switch to complex new app is huge ask
mitigation_strategies: Launch with ONE core feature: 'What's happening tonight?' real-time event feed
Phase 1 (Months 1-3): Event discovery only - no event creation, no social, no reviews
Phase 2 (Months 4-6): Add event creation (free tier only)
Phase 3 (Months 7-9): Add basic social (check-ins, friend activity)
Phase 4 (Months 10-12): Add reviews and business listings
RULE: Ship one feature excellently vs ten features poorly
User testing at every phase - only add next feature if satisfaction >4.5/5.0
identified_risks.success_criteria: App Store rating >4.5, primary feature (event discovery) used by >80% of users weekly

identified_risks.risk_name: User Acquisition Costs Exceeded Revenue by 10x
identified_risks.description: Paid ads on Facebook/Google cost $15-30 per install. Only 5% converted to premium ($10/month). CAC was $300, LTV was $30. Burned $3M on ads with negative unit economics. Viral loops failed - no one invited friends because no friends were on platform.
identified_risks.failure_mode: Assumed 'build it and they will come'. No organic growth strategy. Relied on paid acquisition. Competed against Google/Facebook who have infinite ad budgets. Referral program offered generic '$5 credit' instead of compelling incentives.
evidence_from_research: 92% of local engagement on 4 established platforms - huge switching costs
Travel app market dominated by incumbents with massive marketing budgets
Users already have 3-5 discovery apps - high friction to adopt new one
mitigation_strategies: Organic-first strategy: Partner with local influencers, bloggers, event organizers
B2B2C: Partner with venues/breweries who promote app to their audience
Content marketing: City guides, 'Best of' lists, SEO-optimized blog
Viral loops: 'Invite 3 friends to event' = free premium month
Ambassador program: Pay college students $500/month to evangelize on campus
PR strategy: Launch parties in each city with local media coverage
Community building: Host monthly 'What's Poppin!' meetups for power users
Freemium focus: Keep free tier valuable to maximize word-of-mouth
identified_risks.success_criteria: 50% of users acquired organically, CAC <$10, LTV:CAC ratio >3:1, 20% referral rate

identified_risks.risk_name: Google/Eventbrite Copied Best Features in 6 Months
identified_risks.description: Google added 'Events Near You' tab to Maps. Eventbrite dropped fees to 3%. Facebook Events redesigned discovery feed. Incumbents crushed startup before it reached scale. Users saw no reason to switch from familiar apps with similar features.
identified_risks.failure_mode: Built copyable features (event feed, maps integration) instead of defensible moats. No network effects because no social features. No proprietary data or AI. Commoditized product with no competitive advantage.
evidence_from_research: Google Maps dominates local search (20% of all local searches)
Eventbrite rated 4.7/5.0 with professional features and brand trust
Apple Maps, Yelp, TripAdvisor have massive existing user bases
mitigation_strategies: Build defensible moat: Strong community and social features (hard to copy)
Network effects: Value increases with more users (friends' activity, group plans)
Proprietary data: User preferences, attendance patterns, AI recommendations
Vertical focus: Dominate specific niches (music events, food/drink, outdoor activities)
Local expertise: Deep city knowledge, curated recommendations (not algorithmic)
Brand loyalty: Build cult following with exceptional UX and community
Speed: Move faster than incumbents - ship features weekly, not quarterly
Partnerships: Exclusive venue/organizer relationships lock out competitors
identified_risks.success_criteria: 50% of users cite 'community' as reason for staying, 10,000 exclusive events not on competitors

identified_risks.risk_name: Fake Events, Scams, and Safety Issues Destroyed Brand
identified_risks.description: Spam events flooded platform. Fake ticket sellers scammed users. Meetup locations were unsafe. Sexual harassment at events. No moderation team. Press coverage: 'Dangerous app enables crime'. App stores threatened delisting for policy violations.
identified_risks.failure_mode: Prioritized growth over safety. No event verification. No user reporting system. No background checks on organizers. First safety incident went viral on Twitter, destroying trust permanently.
evidence_from_research: City Discovery users reported fraud (payment issues, cancelled tours, no refunds)
Trust issues major pain point for event/tour platforms
Meetup has low 3.0 satisfaction - community platforms struggle with quality
mitigation_strategies: Pre-launch: Trusted organizers only (verification required: website, social proof, ID)
Event moderation: Manual review of all events in first 6 months
User reporting: One-tap 'Report Event' with 24-hour response SLA
Safety features: Location sharing with friends, 'Emergency' button, SafeRide integrations
Insurance: Partner with event insurance providers for organizer protection
Community guidelines: Clear policies, proactive education, zero tolerance for violations
Background checks: Required for organizers hosting events with alcohol or minors
Ratings: Rate organizers and events - auto-hide low-rated content
identified_risks.success_criteria: Zero major safety incidents in Year 1, <0.1% event reports, 4.5+ organizer rating average

identified_risks.risk_name: Users Refused to Pay, Revenue Assumptions Collapsed
identified_risks.description: Assumed 5-10% freemium conversion. Actual: 0.8%. Users unwilling to pay for discovery app when Google Maps is free. Event organizers chose free tier with ads. Business listings had zero takers ($200/month too expensive). Revenue was 90% below projections.
identified_risks.failure_mode: Premium features weren't valuable enough. Free tier had too much functionality. Ads were annoying but not blocking core use. No pricing experimentation. Waited 12 months to monetize - too late to pivot.
evidence_from_research: Users expect free discovery (Google Maps, Yelp, Facebook Events all free)
Eventbrite fees (7.4%) criticized but tolerated - users don't want to pay directly
Travel apps have low retention - hard to justify subscription for infrequent use
mitigation_strategies: Monetize organizers, not users (B2B model more reliable than B2C)
Transaction fees on paid events (2% vs Eventbrite 7.4%) - lower but higher volume
Business partnerships: Premium listings ($50-100/month) with ROI tracking
Sponsored discovery: Businesses pay for top placement in 'Food' or 'Nightlife' categories
Data licensing: Anonymized event trends sold to city planners, tourism boards
White-label: License platform to tourism bureaus, convention centers
Affiliate revenue: Ticketmaster/StubHub integration for concerts, sports
Start monetization on Day 1: Test pricing early, iterate based on data
identified_risks.success_criteria: Multiple revenue streams (not dependent on single model), $5+ ARPU by Month 6, profitability path by Month 12

identified_risks.risk_name: App Performance Issues Caused Mass Uninstalls
identified_risks.description: Slow load times (5+ seconds), frequent crashes, battery drain, excessive data usage. Users complained app killed their phone. 1-star reviews: 'Laggy and unreliable'. Poor maps performance vs Google Maps. Push notifications arrived hours late or not at all.
identified_risks.failure_mode: Built with wrong tech stack. Didn't optimize for mobile performance. No load testing before launch. Database couldn't scale past 10K users. Real-time features (event updates) were actually 15-minute delays.
evidence_from_research: City discovery apps criticized for technical issues (attachments not opening, payment failures)
Users expect Google Maps-level performance (instant, reliable, accurate)
Mobile app users have zero tolerance for bugs - uninstall immediately
mitigation_strategies: Choose proven tech stack: React Native or Flutter for cross-platform, Firebase for backend
Performance budget: 2-second load time, 60fps scrolling, <50MB app size
Load testing: Simulate 100K users before launch
CDN for media: Images/videos served from edge network
Optimize maps: Use MapBox or Google Maps SDK with caching
Push notification infrastructure: Reliable provider (OneSignal, Airship)
Monitoring: Real-time error tracking (Sentry), performance monitoring (Firebase Performance)
Beta testing: 1,000 users for 8 weeks before public launch
identified_risks.success_criteria: App Store rating >4.5, crash rate <0.1%, 95th percentile load time <2s, <5% uninstalls due to performance

priority_order: 1. R1 - Cold Start (must solve before launch)

pre_launch: R1: Partner with 50+ organizers to seed 500+ events in launch city
R1: Build 10,000 waitlist through landing page, local PR, influencers
R3: Define MVP as event discovery ONLY - cut all other features
R6: Implement event verification and moderation workflow
R8: 8-week beta with 1,000 users, fix all critical bugs
month_1_3: R1: Launch in single city (Austin), aim for 10,000 users and 1,000 events/month
R2: Implement push notifications, daily digest, basic gamification
R4: Organic growth focus - local partnerships, PR, ambassador program
R6: Manual moderation of all events, <24hr response to reports
R7: Test monetization - business listings at $50/month, event fees at 2%
month_4_6: R2: Add social features (check-ins, friend activity) to boost retention
R3: Add event creation tools if discovery satisfaction >4.5/5.0
R4: Optimize referral program based on data, target 20% invite rate
R5: Build defensible moat with proprietary data and community
R7: Multiple revenue experiments - find model with >$5 ARPU
month_7_12: R1: Expand to 2-3 additional cities only if launch city thriving
R2: Target 15% day-30 retention (5x industry average)
R5: 10,000 exclusive events not on competitors
R7: Path to profitability visible, multiple revenue streams live

pre_launch_go_decision.if_criteria_not_met: Delay launch, do not proceed until gates passed

month_3_expand_decision.if_criteria_not_met: Do not expand to new cities, fix launch city first

month_6_series_a_decision.if_criteria_not_met: Pivot or shutdown before burning more capital

key_lessons_from_research: Travel apps have worst retention in industry (2.8%) - must design for daily utility, not episodic use
Two-sided marketplaces fail without critical mass - seed supply (events) before demanding users
Incumbents (Google, Eventbrite, Yelp) have massive advantages - need defensible moat (community, data, speed)
Trust and safety issues can destroy brand overnight - proactive moderation is mandatory
Feature bloat kills startups - launch with ONE excellent feature, add iteratively
Users expect free discovery (Google Maps) - monetize organizers/businesses, not end users
Organic growth is only sustainable model - paid ads have terrible CAC for consumer apps
Mobile performance is non-negotiable - users uninstall buggy apps immediately
